result.execSummary:
The defendant James A. Berg was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Resisting or Obstructing an Officer, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.41(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Failure to pay any part of the fine or court costs in full by the due date will result in 1 day jail for each $25 left unpaid.  $15.00 payment plan fee added.
Sentence to start on or before June 1, 2015 at 6 pm.  May serve on EMP according to jail rules.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt: Paid fine in full at CCAP website

ADA Melissa Inlow appears for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney French.  Defendant plead no contest to Count 2.  Count 1 dismissed and read in for sentencing purposes.  Court reviewed plea questionnaire, constitutional rights and elements with the defendant.  Defendant understood.  Defense stipulated to factual basis.  Court found that the defendant freely voluntarily and intelligently entered his plea, and waived his constitutional rights.  Factual basis exists.  Found guilty as plead to.   ADA Inlow recommended 60 days jail.  Attorney French agrees and this is a joint recommendation.  Defendant elected to not exercise his right to allocution.  Court ordered 60 days jail, to start on or before June 1, 2015 at 6 pm.  May serve on EMP, if he qualifies.  CC.  DNA surcharge.  CC pay @ $50 per month starting 6/1/15.    Failure to pay any part of the fine or court costs in full by the due date will result in 1 day jail for each $25 left unpaid.
Status cancelled per Atty. French.  Set for plea and sentencing

Pre-trial conference at 03-11-2015 09:00 am.
Status conference at 03-30-2015 03:00 pm.

Defendant appeared with counsel Molly French.  Melissa Inlow appears for the State.  Wavied reading of complaint and entered not guilty pleas.  Court set pretrial for 3-11 and status for 3-30-15 at 3:00.  Bond is continued.
From attorney Molly French along with Demand for Discovery

Defendant appeared without counsel.  Melissa Inlow appears for the State.  Defendant acknowledges receipt of complaint.  He has contacted SPDO but needs to take a copy of his pay stub there to determine if eligible for representation.  Court adjourned 1 week and notified defendant that if he doesn't qualify for SPD that he can petition for representation and he should do so right away.  Given return date and bond was continued.

DA Fox appeared on behalf of the State.  Defendant appeared in person and without counsel.  Court advised defendant the charges and possible penalties.  Defendant wants an attorney.  Court explained options to defendant.  AIA set for 2/9/15 at 9:30 am.

Report for Booking.    Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request.  No violent, abusive, threatening or disorderly contact with: Tiffany K
